More news out on the Wisconsin debate issue. Mrs. Clinton is now staying through Tuesday, but Mr. Obama is now leaving earlier. Here's an exchange between the Clinton/Obama campaign on why Mr. Obama won't debate: 
 
 Still dueling over debates
 By Craig Gilbert
 Sunday, Feb 17 2008, 01:50 PM
 The debate debate between the Clinton and Obama campaigns flared up again on "Face the Nation" this morning. Clinton accepted and Obama rejected an invitation for a televised Wisconsin debate before Tuesday's primary. The two will debate two more times in other states.
 
 Howard Wolfson of the Clinton campaign and David Axelrod of the Obama campaign clashed over the issue on the CBS program hosted by Bob Schieffer this morning. Here are selected excerpts from the show:
 
 SCHIEFFER: David Axelrod, Senator Clinton wants more debates. Why not more debates?
 Mr. AXELROD: Well, we have one coming up next Thursday in Texas, Bob, and one five days later in Ohio. We've debated 18 times already, this would make 19 and 20 ... Debates are important, and we want to participate them, but it--in them, but it's also important to go out, meet people, have interchanges with voters, have town hall meetings ...
 SCHIEFFER: With all respect, aren't you just doing what people do when they think they're the front-runner? If you're ahead, you don't debate; if you're not ahead, you say `let's debate.' Isn't that really what you're doing here? ....
 Mr. WOLFSON: The Obama strategy here is essentially to debate in states where they're behind, but not debate in states where they're ahead.
 Mr. AXELROD: That's nonsense.
 Mr. WOLFSON: Well, you're debating in Ohio and Texas...
 Mr. AXELROD: That's nonsense.
 Mr. WOLFSON: ...where you're behind, but you don't want to debate in Wisconsin, where you're ahead. That's flat--that's certainly the case.
 Mr. AXELROD: Well, first of all, I don't know whether we're ahead or behind in Wisconsin, but I appreciate the encouragement.
 Mr. WOLFSON: Well, polls say that you're ahead. Polls say that you're ahead.
 Mr. AXELROD: It's a very close race in Wisconsin, but the point is, Howard...
 Mr. WOLFSON: Polls say you're ahead.

 Ask yourself these questions:  1. What is the goal of the health insurance industry?  2. What value added does the health insurance industry bring to the health care system?  
 
 The answers to these questions are simple: 1. The goal of the health insurance industry is to make money for the companys' management and investors. Whether subscribers receive quality health care is almost completely irrelevant. In fact, the system provides a disincentive to providing good health care (see question 2).  2. Health insurance companies only value added is to manage an actuarial pool of subscribers. But profit incentives are such that denying service is rewarded and providing service is not. In addition, to maximize profit insurance companies are incentivized to cherry pick "low risk" subscribers, thus excluding those who need health insurance the most.  
 
 The only health insurance system that can be both cost effective and meet the needs of all citizens is one in which everyone is part of the actuarial the pool, and the objective is to provide quality health care, not to turn a profit. This is, of course, a single payer plan managed either by the government of a charted non-profit corporation. Any systems that is based on free-market style competition between private insurance companies will fail in its primary and only goal legitimate: to provide high quality health care to all citizens.
